awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Interfacial Engineering for Stabilizing Hybrid Perovskites and Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
Non-Technical Summary
Highly efficient and low-cost light emitting diodes (LEDs) are critical for the future energy landscape in the United States. They are widely used in displays and lighting. Current technologies use high temperature and high vacuum for materials processing and device fabrication, which are energy- and infrastructure-demanding. In this project, LED devices based on a new type of semiconductors—the so-called organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites—will be studied. These materials exhibit excellent optical and optoelectronic properties required for LED applications. In addition, they can be processed at low temperature under mild conditions, making the device fabrication and integration much easier. This research will enable future LED devices that are scalable and cost-effective. This project will also provide interdisciplinary training to undergraduate and graduate students, providing them with critical-thinking and problem-solving skills needed for future careers in areas of semiconductor technology.

Technical Summary
Organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites have shown tremendous potential for low-cost, energy-efficient optoelectronics (e.g. LEDs and solar cells). Development of viable devices based on the perovskites, however, has been inhibited by materials and device instability. Among the factors that are responsible for the performance loss, ion migration appears to be intrinsic to this new class of semiconductors and remains challenging to be circumvented. This project aims to identify new ways to stabilize perovskite-LEDs by interfacial engineering. Three questions that are critical to the success of the proposed research will be answered: (1) which interface in perovskite devices is more vulnerable to ion migration? (2) could the ion migration be suppressed by introducing “extrinsic” interlayers at the grain boundary and interface? (3) what are the suitable techniques for implementing such interlayers? Leveraging comprehensive expertise on materials chemistry and device physics, the collaborative team will unravel fundamental roles of the interfaces in materials degradation and provide a practical strategy for stabilizing perovskite devices. The ultimate goal of the project is to break the current ceiling of device stability and demonstrate perovskite-LEDs with > 1000-hour operation lifetime. On a broader scope, the approach of interfacial engineering established in this project will also be applicable to other perovskite devices such as solar cells and photodetectors, which share many common features with perovskite-LEDs from materials selection to device architecture.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Organic-inorganic hybrid perovskites, with excellent optical and electrical properties and facile synthetic approaches, are promising for high-performance, low-cost optoelectronics. Rapid performance loss during continuous device operation, however, inhibits the development towards viable applications. The PIs tackle this challenge by implementing stabilizing, functional interfaces in perovskite-LEDs. Material interfaces play important roles in facilitating ion migration—a major factor that is responsible for chemical and structural disruptions and limits the device lifetime. Being intrinsic to this new class of hybrid semiconductors, ion migration remains quite challenging to be circumvented. Leveraging sophisticated molecular assembly and atomic layer deposition techniques, the proposed research answers two critical questions: (1) could nanoscale interlayers suppress the ion migration and protect the chemical integrity of the interfaces while retaining the desirable electrical functionality? (2) how could such interlayers be implemented in a tunable and controllable manner? The results will advance fundamental understandings of the roles that interfaces play in device degradation, and demonstrate a new strategy to build perovskite-LEDs with unprecedented lifespan.

 

Through the course of this award, the project was able to establish the synthesis and fabrication of a series of organic-inorganic hybrid quantum wells emitters under mild conditions and demonstrated highly efficient and stable LED devices. For example, the team synthesized and characterized wavelength-tunable phase pure hybrid quantum well via increasing the conjugation length and molecular rigidity of organic semiconductor ligands. Furthermore, the team reported fabrication of thin film light-emitting diodes using these hybrid materials and achieved external quantum efficiency over 25% and operational lifetime over 200 hours, which were the highest in the literature. Thus, this project has established a clear path by which to launch a new avenue of research in this emerging subfield of perovskite semiconductor emitters and lighting technologies, and it has provided an infrastructure that could reasonably launch translational of these materials to market in the not-too-distant future as well.

 

In addition to the outcomes associated with laboratory work, this project was instrumental in advancing key educational programs as well. For example, the graduate students and postdoctoral researchers supported by this project has published several high-impact scientific papers. They gained significant scientific training and are prepared for their independent career. One has completed his postdoctoral training and become a professor in South Korea. This award has led to the direct training of several undergraduate and visiting undergraduate students as well. During this time, the students have been trained on experimental techniques that have improved their materials chemistry, device fabrication, and device physics knowledge to a significant degree. Moreover, they have been able to interact with mentors such that they have a better feel for how this work fits into their future career plans as the undergraduate student aims to go to graduate school. Through all of these efforts, we believe that this work has significantly improved the technology and training landscape of the United States.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2024
Modified by: Letian Dou
